description: Karunarathnage Robert Seneviratne Tennakoon Vs The Divisional Secretary of Kobeigane and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Karunarathnage Robert Seneviratne Tennakoon Vs The Divisional Secretary of Kobeigane and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The Petitioner being the eldest child of the original permit holder, who had died and nominated his wife as the successor, sought to be substituted. The same permit holder held two plots of land, one on permit issued under the Land Development Ordinance, and the other one’s permit was on the pipeline to be issued. The widow never made an application to succeed within the time stipulated as she had also died within sixteen months of the death of the original permit holder. The Divisional Secretary decided to amalgamate both lands and divided into equal shares among all the children. The Petitioner successfully invoked the jurisdiction of this Court to obtain a Writ of Certiorari and Mandamus to declare him as the successor in respect of the plot of land held under permit.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: Neshakumaran Vimalaraj Vs The University Grants Commission and Others before Hon.Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Neshakumaran Vimalaraj Vs The University Grants Commission and Others
judgement_by: Hon.Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The Petitioner was a Council Member of the Eastern University for a period of three years. After the present Government came into power, the members of the University Grants Commission were newly appointed and they requested the Petitioner to resign from his said post; on refusal, he was removed. The said decision was challenged by way of writ. The main defense taken up by the Respondents was that the Petitioner was removed in implementing National policy. However, the National policy that was relied upon was the election manifesto of a political party. Held – no election manifesto can be accepted or adopted as National policy if it is violative of the law and Constitution, unless the law and Constitution are changed. Writ of Certiorari and Mandamus was issued.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: Thillaiampalavanar Vimalan Vs The University Grants Commission and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.

keywords: The Petitioner was a Council Member of the Jaffna University for a period of three years. After the present Government came into power, the members of the University Grants Commission were newly appointed and they requested the Petitioner to resign from his said post; on refusal, he was removed. The said decision was challenged by way of writ. The main defense taken up by the Respondents was that the Petitioner was removed in implementing National policy. However, the National policy that was relied upon was the election manifesto of a political party. Held – no election manifesto can be accepted or adopted as National policy if it is violative of the law and Constitution, unless the law and Constitution are changed. Writ of Certiorari and Mandamus was issued.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

parties: Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment Vs Sarath Chandrasiri Withana, Arbitrator and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The Petitioner is the Foreign Employment Bureau, who advertised to fill the vacancies in the Administrative Class of the cadre internally. The 4th to 22nd Respondents were among the candidates who had applied; however, they did not obtain the required marks. A dispute arose and the matter was referred to arbitration. The arbitral award was granted in favour of the 4th to 22nd Respondent, however, it did not consider the fact that there were no vacancies existing at the time to absorb them into the cadre. Writ of Certiorari and Prohibition issued quashing the said arbitral award.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: Karunarathnage Robert Seneviratne Tennakoon Vs The Divisional Secretary of Kobeigane and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Karunarathnage Robert Seneviratne Tennakoon Vs The Divisional Secretary of Kobeigane and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The Petitioner being the eldest child of the original permit holder, who had died and nominated his wife as the successor, sought to be substituted. The same permit holder held two plots of land, one on permit issued under the Land Development Ordinance, and the other one’s permit was on the pipeline to be issued. The widow never made an application to succeed within the time stipulated as she had also died within sixteen months of the death of the original permit holder. The Divisional Secretary decided to amalgamate both lands and divided into equal shares among all the children. The Petitioner successfully invoked the jurisdiction of this Court to obtain a Writ of Certiorari and Mandamus to declare him as the successor in respect of the plot of land held under permit.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: Neshakumaran Vimalaraj Vs The University Grants Commission and Others before Hon.Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Neshakumaran Vimalaraj Vs The University Grants Commission and Others
judgement_by: Hon.Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The Petitioner was a Council Member of the Eastern University for a period of three years. After the present Government came into power, the members of the University Grants Commission were newly appointed and they requested the Petitioner to resign from his said post; on refusal, he was removed. The said decision was challenged by way of writ. The main defense taken up by the Respondents was that the Petitioner was removed in implementing National policy. However, the National policy that was relied upon was the election manifesto of a political party. Held – no election manifesto can be accepted or adopted as National policy if it is violative of the law and Constitution, unless the law and Constitution are changed. Writ of Certiorari and Mandamus was issued.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: Thillaiampalavanar Vimalan Vs The University Grants Commission and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.

The said decision was challenged by way of writ. The main defense taken up by the Respondents was that the Petitioner was removed in implementing National policy. However, the National policy that was relied upon was the election manifesto of a political party. Held – no election manifesto can be accepted or adopted as National policy if it is violative of the law and Constitution, unless the law and Constitution are changed. legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: Dr. Wijendra Patabendalage Ranjith Kusumsiri and Another Vs. Commissioner General of the Department of Ayurveda and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J
parties: Dr. Wijendra Patabendalage Ranjith Kusumsiri and Another Vs. Commissioner General of the Department of Ayurveda and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J
keywords: Two Ayurveda doctors attached to the Department of Ayurveda challenged the appointment of the 12th Respondent - When the former Provincial Director retired, applications were called for to fill up the vacancy; however, the applications and interviews were cancelled due to technical difficulties. For the interim, the 12th Respondent was appointed to cover-up the appointment of the Provincial Director. Held – there is a slight difference between a ‘cover-up appointment’ and ‘acting appointment’; a covering up appointment is only until a new person is appointed. Thus, no writ lies
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: Dadallage Shanthilatha Vs The Divisional Secretary of Kekirawa and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Dadallage Shanthilatha Vs The Divisional Secretary of Kekirawa and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: Before the original grantee’s death, he had bequeathed the rights to the land in suit, to the 5th Respondent through his Last Will. The 5 th Respondent instituted a vindicatory action to eject the Petitioner from the land in suit granted to the original grantee by Section 19(4) of the Land Development Ordinance. The Petitioner sought to invoke writ jurisdiction, challenging the acceptance of the 5th Respondent as the successor, mainly on grounds of violation of the rules of natural justice, and failure to succeed in terms of Chapter XXXVIII of the Civil Procedure Code and Section 64 of the Ordinance. Held – no writ lies.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: Naththandige Indra Chandana Anton Fernando Vs The Divisional Secretary of Wennapuwa and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Naththandige Indra Chandana Anton Fernando Vs The Divisional Secretary of Wennapuwa and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The original grantee had passed away without nominating a successor; thus, his spouse became the life interest holder in terms of Section 48B of the Land Development Ordinance. She had nominated the 5th Respondent, who is the sibling of the Petitioner, as the successor, which was accepted and registered by the 1st Respondent. The Petitioner challenged the said acceptance and registration of the 5th Respondent as the successor. Writ of Certiorari issued since the decision contravenes Section 48B. However, refused to issue a Writ of Mandamus to consider the Petitioner as the successor to the life interest holder since that question does not arise until her demise.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: The Sri Lanka Transport Board Vs Malintha Jayasinghe, the Arbitrator and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: The Sri Lanka Transport Board Vs Malintha Jayasinghe, the Arbitrator and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The 2nd Respondent is an employee under the Petitioner as a driver, who was involved in an accident that resulted in the death of a passerby; he was then prosecuted before the Magistrate’s Court, exonerated from all charges, and reinstated without back wages. The dispute was referred to arbitration, and the arbitral award in favour of the 2nd Respondent was granted. When the Petitioner challenged the said arbitral award, notice was refused since the arbitrator is justified in granting the award after having properly considered all the evidence.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

keywords: Offence of rape – Rape remains a widespread and growing issue in Sri Lanka, casting a long shadow over the nation’s social fabric. It is not merely a crime; it is a curse that strikes at the very heart of the community. It leaves psychological scars on the victims and instils fear among women in society. Addressing this harrowing issue is essential for fostering safety, respect and dignity for all – The issue concerns the fact that the sentence is disproportionate and excessive - Determination of the appropriate punishment to sex offenders – Aggravating circumstances as regards to the offence of rape.
legistation: Section 364(2) of the Penal Code

parties: Hamburugala Withanage Kelum Sujeewa Abewickrama Vs Hon. Attorney General,
keywords: Murder – Robbery – One of the key evidentiary matters is the use of dying declarations – Under the maxim “nemo moriturus praesumitur mentiri” – dying declarations are treated as a recognised exception to the hearsay rule – A person facing imminent death without hope of recovery, is believed to have a heightened moral and spiritual obligation to speak the truth – Despite the presumption of trustworthiness, dying declarations are not free from weaknesses – Courts must carefully evaluate their reliability – Discrepancies between the dying declaration and the accused’s dock statement.
legistation: Section 32(1) of the Evidence Ordinance No.14 of 1895 - Section 126A, 436 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Act No.15 of 1979 (as amended)

keywords: The Petitioner, as an entrepreneur, had invested money in an apartment housing complex by purchasing shares thereof — a nuisance caused by certain three-wheel drivers, parking their three- wheels, causing a hindrance at the entrance of the housing complex. The Petitioner made a police complaint for the police to prosecute them for public nuisance. The Magistrate Court refused to entertain a charge based on that; however, entertained a charge of criminal trespass. Writ is sought against the police, compelling them to charge the said three-wheel drivers with public nuisance. Application was refused since evidence has to be considered, and the Petitioner can still obtain relief from the District Court.

description: Amarathunga Arachchige Kapila Sampath Perera Vs The Minister of Lands and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Amarathunga Arachchige Kapila Sampath Perera Vs The Minister of Lands and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The original grantee had died and, before his death, had placed the 4 th Respondent in possession under a tenancy agreement, without permission of the Divisional Secretary, violating the conditions of the original grant. The Petitioner, who is the heir of the original grantee, seeks a writ against the Divisional Secretary for his decision to hold an inquiry to decide whether the Petitioner is entitled to the grant or whether the 4th and 5th Respondents, who are in possession, are entitled. Application was refused since it is the Divisional Secretary who should take a decision and, without going into evidence, this Court cannot decide.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka; Land Development Ordinance

description: Kaluthota Investments and Leasing (Pvt) Ltd., and Loku Kaluthotage Nandasena Vs Ginthota Sarukkali Patebendige and 90 Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Kaluthota Investments and Leasing (Pvt) Ltd., and Loku Kaluthotage Nandasena Vs Ginthota Sarukkali Patebendige and 90 Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: Partition action instituted in the District Court of Tangalle in respect of land situated within the same jurisdiction. Allegations that the entire land has not been depicted in the preliminary plan. However, before the commencement of the trial, the Petitioner sought the intervention of the writ court to obtain a writ compelling the District Court Judge to dismiss the action for the want of proper identification of the corpus. Held – the writ court cannot intervene into the matter since it affects the Judicial power of the parties since only the District Court of Tangalle has the jurisdiction in terms of Section 3(2) of the Partition Law, Section 6 of the Civil Procedure Code, and the Constitution. Though the writ court is empowered to issue writs, when there is no allegation of irrationality, act of ultra vires affecting the rights of the parties, or acted without evidence, no writ lies.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

description: M.W. Oshan Weerasinghe Vs Director General of Customs of the Bandaranayake International Airport and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: M.W. Oshan Weerasinghe Vs Director General of Customs of the Bandaranayake International Airport and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: The Customs Ordinance conviction under Section 12 and 43, read with the Import and Export Control Act No. 01 of 1969 and Gazette bearing No. 1953/28, on the importation of fourteen gold biscuits without a license issued thereunder. Entitlement of the Petitioner to obtain such a license if the opportunity was not given. Nevertheless, after conviction, the Petitioner has exercised his right to appeal twice and obtained relief. Therefore, no writ lies.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, and the Customs Ordinance.

description: Raj Rajaratnam Vs Governor of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka and Others before Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
parties: Raj Rajaratnam Vs Governor of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka and Others
judgement_by: Hon. Dr. D. F. H. Gunawardhana, J.
keywords: A sum of 3 Millon rupees was sent to Sri Lanka by the Petitioner to purchase shares in a commercial bank without prior permission of the Central Bank or the Department of Foreign Exchange – An investigation was conducted followed by a freezing order; resulted in a High Court indictment, which ended in a withdrawal and the Petitioner was never accused or indicted. The Respondents refused to uplift the freezing order or direct the 5th Respondent to release the money. The Petitioner is entitled to obtain a writ since the investigations conducted under the Foreign Exchange Control Act, No. 24 of 1953 ceased to exist upon the promulgation of the Foreign Exchange Act, No. 12 of 2017.
legistation: The Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka; Foreign Exchange Control Act, No. 24 of 1953; Foreign Exchange Act, No. 12 of 2017

keywords: In a criminal case, it is the prosecution’s duty to prove its case beyond a reasonable doubt. This high standard of proof is a fundamental principle of the justice system, designed to protect the accused from wrongful conviction and endure that only those who are truly guilty are punished. When the prosecution fails to present sufficient evidence to meet the standard, it is only just and reasonable to afford the benefit of the doubt to the accused.

keywords: Grave sexual abuse on a minor – Minimum mandatory sentence - Discretion of a Trial Judge to reach a conclusion as regards to a sentence is not inhibited or controlled by a mandatory sentence imposed by a stature, however there should be some adequate reasons to do so – Aggravating circumstances present, public interest demands that a custodial sentence be imposed on the appellant as convictions for grave sexual abuse carries significant implications not just for the victim but for the society as a whole – The legal consequences imposed on individuals convicted of grave sexual abuse are designed to reflect the seriousness of the crime.

description: The Director General, Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption, Vs. 1. Thotamuna Kankanamage Wasantha Kumara, 2. Upali Gamini Jayawardhana, before Hon. Amal Ranaraja, J.
parties: The Director General, Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption, Vs. 1. Thotamuna Kankanamage Wasantha Kumara, 2. Upali Gamini Jayawardhana,
keywords: • Bribery • Director General of the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption filed indictment against the accused-respondents for soliciting and accepting money as a gratification from a particular individual to perform their official duties. • Preliminary Objection that the Commission has to initiate investigations collectively. • Powers of the Commission • Allegations of bribery or corruption can arise at any moment, necessitating prompt and effective investigation. If the legislature intended for the Commission to conduct investigations collectively, it becomes evident that such requirement would lead to an absurd situation. The need for immediate action in response to allegations cannot be overstated, delays in investigations would not only hinder justice but also undermine public trust in the integrity of the institution. • Revisionary Jurisdiction of the Court of Appeal is a discretionary remedy and becomes necessary for this Court to consider the conditions upon which the discr

judgement_by: Hon. M. T. MOHAMMED LAFFAR, J
keywords: Distinction between Judicial review and Appeal-Judicial review is radically different from the system of Appeals -Grounds of Appeal cannot be considered as grounds for judicial review. The power of Arbitrator is much wider and his decision should be just and equitable - The Arbitrator is empowered to disregard laches in delivering a just and equitable orders as he has wide discretionary powers.
legistation: Industrial Dispute Act No. 53 of 1973 (As Amended) Article 140 of the Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka.

description: Munamalpe Gamage Dhamith Sameera Vs Commissioner of Co-operative Development and Registrar (Central Province) and Two others before Hon.M SampathK.B.Wijeratne,J.(CA)
parties: Munamalpe Gamage Dhamith Sameera Vs Commissioner of Co-operative Development and Registrar (Central Province) and Two others
keywords: Two different decision of the Supreme Court on the Rule 49 (xii)(a) - In one judgement holds that the Rule is ultra vires and in the other its intra vires– In the former it is obiter dictum and the later it is ratiodecidendi – Doctrine of stare decisis – The test to be applied in deciding whether it is obiter dictum or ratio decidendi–The words ‘appears to be’ used in the judgement- No certainty in the mind of the judge – Not a definitive finding – re-arguing the same issue in courts repeatedly – Unproductive practice – Has to be discouraged – the learned High Court Judge failed to address the other issue raised by the Petition – Part of the judgement affirm but set a side the judgement dismissing the writ application in its entirely - case remitted back to the high Court to make a determination on the other issue.
legistation: Sections 59 and 61 Co-operative Societies Law Act No. 5 of 1972. Article 38 and 72 (2) of the Co0operative Societies Statute No. 10 of 1990 of the Central Provincial Counsil, as amended. Rule 49 (xii)(a) and (b) of the Co-operative Societies Rules, 1973 – published in Extraordinary Gazette No. 93/5 dated 10th January 1973.
